headline.main: Pilgrimage to New York City: Paying Respects and Spending Little

docs.abstract: Businesses in downtown Manhattan near World Trade Center site are not faring well, even with influx of tourists visiting ground zero; officials estimate that millions have visited although businesses are reluctant to advertise and be seen as profiting from tragedy of attacks; even so, there is no way to track visitors to downtown area or their spending, according to Cristyne L Nicholas, president of NYC & Company; photos (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: Those who market New York City to tourists face a delicate problem. The city is desperate to attract visitors to spend money, especially downtown, where businesses have been suffering since the Sept. 11 terrorist attack. But the biggest tourist attraction downtown, and probably in the city, is the site of that attack. And the thousands of people who visit it every day are proving to be tourists of a sort that the city has never seen before. ''It's a sad tourist,'' explained Rachelle Friedman, co-owner of J & R Music and Computer World, across Broadway on Park Row not far from the disaster site. ''It's not the same kind of tourist at all.''
docs.snippet: Those who market New York City to tourists face a delicate problem. The city is desperate to attract visitors to spend money, especially downtown, where businesses have been suffering since the Sept. 11 terrorist attack. But the biggest tourist at...

headline.main: Good Times Now Roll a Little Later

docs.lead_paragraph: A drunken man draped with Mardi Gras beads lurched out of a French Quarter bar, his drink sloshing over the lip of his plastic cup. Couples linked arms or danced in the street as hip-hop music blared from clubs, and on each corner groups of police officers stood and watched. The clock was ticking on Bourbon Street.
docs.snippet: Revelers took the partying on New Orleans's most famous street past midnight for the first time since Katrina, after the curfew was extended to 2 a.m....

headline.main: Vacant Rooms, Empty Tables, Scared Tourists

docs.section_name: Front Page; Travel; New York and Region
docs.abstract: New York City tourism industry, already in slump because of softening economy, is reeling from terrorist attacks against World Trade Center; drop is so sharp and signs so troubling that many within industry fear problem may go on for months; Mayor Rudolph Giuliani expresses concern; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: At the New York Palace Hotel on Madison Avenue, more than three-quarters of the 1,058 rooms sat empty yesterday. The Plaza Hotel, a Fifth Avenue landmark, is considering closing its famed Oak Room and Oyster Bar because business is so bad. Other restaurants are also suffering; cancellations have turned the catering business at the Rainbow Room, an Art Deco landmark high above Rockefeller Center, into a ghost town.
docs.snippet: At the New York Palace Hotel on Madison Avenue, more than three-quarters of the 1,058 rooms sat empty yesterday. The Plaza Hotel, a Fifth Avenue landmark, is considering closing its famed Oak Room and Oyster Bar because business is so bad.    Othe...

headline.main: Hawaii Reeling as Events on Distant Shores Keep Its Beaches Bare

docs.abstract: Prospects for Hawaii's tourism-dependent economy plunge precipitously in days after terrorist attacks of Sept 11; with tourists reluctant to fly and spend, Hawaii has become forlorn and eerily quiet place; famed beaches are mostly deserted, and most hotels are less than half full; restaurants open late and close early, if they open at all; mood has become so grave that state's normally cautious governor, Benjamin J Cayetano, warns that Hawaii faces 'its worst economic crisis ever' and calls emergency session of state Legislature to borrow $1 billion to stimulate economy; photos (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: It was bad after the Persian Gulf war broke out. It was bad when Hurricane Iniki leveled Kauai in 1992. It was bad, quite frankly, for most of the 1990's, when recessions first in California and then in Japan reverberated here, and Hawaii sat out the mainland boom years. But never have the prospects for Hawaii's tourism-dependent economy plunged as low -- or as quickly -- as in the days since the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11.

headline.main: It's Business Almost as Usual at Mombasa's Beach Resorts

docs.abstract: Relatively few foreign tourists have left Mombasa's beach resorts in wake of terrorist bombing of Israeli-owned hotel; resorts report few cancellations; lounge chairs at hotels are full of vacationers; many Israelis have cut short vacations and returned home; some foreigners express reluctance to stay at hotels known to attract many Israelis; tourism, Kenya's second-largest earner of foreign exchange, had only recently begun to pick up; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Even as investigators pick through the rubble of the bombed-out Paradise Hotel, there are still men leading sluggish camels along the scorching sand of Kenya's picturesque coastline, goading tourists into taking a ride. ''I'm praying the tourists don't go away,'' said Ali Hassan Abdi, 31, who makes a living by charging the equivalent of $6 for a ride on his camel, a sturdy beast named Amsa.

byline.original: By MARC LACEY and DEXTER FILKINS

headline.main: Liberty Island Will Reopen, But With Statue Cordoned Off

docs.abstract: National Park Service will reopen Liberty Island and Ellis Island to tourists, but Statue of Liberty will remain closed at least until next year for security reasons (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Starting Thursday, huddled masses will once again be allowed to visit Ellis Island and Liberty Island, though Lady Liberty herself will remain off limits, a lingering victim of the Sept. 11 terror attacks. The National Park Service, which oversees the landmark, has strengthened security for both islands. But officials said the Statue of Liberty itself would remain off limits at least until next year, though visitors will be free to walk around it.

headline.main: Illness Takes a Toll On Hotels in Asia

docs.abstract: Hotel industry is suffering from severe acute respiratory syndrome outbreak, as guests cancel trips and hotel managers well beyond affected Asian nations take emergency steps to protect guests and employees; Japanese tour companies and corporations suspend travel to Hong Kong and southern China for two weeks after Japan warns 14 Japanese may have contracted SARS; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: The hotel industry is suffering almost as much as the airline industry from outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome, as guests cancel trips and hotel managers take emergency steps to prevent guests and employees from becoming infected. ''Everyone has been affected by it, not only in Asia,'' said David Baffsky, the chairman of the Asian and Pacific operations of Accor S.A., the largest operator of hotels in East Asia. ''It has some quite important consequences not just from a health point of view but a business point of view.''

headline.print_headline: Following Cork From Tree to Bottle
headline.main: In Spain, an Eco-Tour That Follows Cork From Tree to Bottle

docs.abstract: American-based Cork Forest Conservation Alliance is behind creation of From Bark to Bottle; eco-tour leads participants on 11-day trek through cork forests in three regions of Spain, learning about lives of cork harvesters and sampling food and wine of each region.
docs.lead_paragraph: The tour, From Bark to Bottle, accompanies the cork harvest and allows participants to sample the area’s food and wine.
